content.content: Grant Announcement: KYC/AML Compliance Research MakerDAO SES welcomes Patrizia Crespi in support of navigating MakerDAO’s know-your-customer / anti-money laundering (KYC/AML) compliance obligations.  Background Patrizia joins MakerDAO with 16 years of experience working as a legal and compliance professional in the banking industry. She holds an Upper-Second Class Honors bachelor’s degree in Law and a postgraduate degree in Law obtained at the University of Law in London. In addition to these TradFi accolades, Patrizia also holds a certificate in advanced studies in Blockchain from the University of Zurich. Leveraging her years of experience in senior compliance roles for global banking institutions in London, Frankfurt, and Zurich, Patrizia is utilizing the MakerDAO SES Grants program to begin researching risks and solutions for KYC/AML regulatory management. The grant focuses on the Financial Action Task Force’s (FATF) updated guidance for Virtual Assets (VA) and Virtual Asset Service Providers (VASP) published in October 2021. FATF is an independent, inter-governmental organization. Their purpose is to set policies to protect international financial systems against money laundering and terror financing. FATF’s guidance and recommendations are recognized as the global standard governments should aim for when creating laws and regulations. It’s important to highlight that the guidance published by FATF is not law. However, more than 200 countries adhere to FATF’s guidance. The October 2021 report introduced 6 key areas MakerDAO needs to be mindful of when tackling growth this year. Estimates assume nations will soon act on this guidance and enact laws that will impact MakerDAO in the next 12 months.  Grant Details Three deliverables are defined within the scope of this grant. They are:  A Feasibility Study advising on the impact of potential new laws and regulations based on FATF’s guidance on DeFi and stable coins. The selection of AML tool(s) for MakerDAO with a demo conducted for the community to review. Serve as a point of contact for external compliance relations and queries for MakerDAO.  The estimated timeline for this initial grant was scoped at 3 months, starting in January with a budget of 1,500 Dai/month. Today we’re excited to announce that Patrizia’s scope of work will already be increasing as she plays a pivotal role in building out the compliance track for SES’s Legal Core Unit incubator cohort.  SES Incubator Season 1: Legal Cohort In Q2 2022, MakerDAO SES will restructure its Incubator and Grants program to enable the incubation of up to 5 candidate facilitators per educational track. This means instead of incubating at most 6 core units at a time, the focus will be on preparing potentially 10-15 facilitators to run individual core units across 3 unique education tracks. Patrizia will help ensure the legal incubation track accomplishes the goal of setting up the critical legal infrastructure for MakerDAO. The SES Legal tracks will focus on:  RWA Legal Regulatory Compliance Advocacy & Public Policy Legal Entity Incorporation Services Legal Proxy / Legal advice coordination (TBD) Insurance  Patrizia’s grant will continue into March of 2022, with a final report delivered to the MakerDAO community covering the deliverables above. With SES’s incubator restructuring, an additional deliverable of defining the mandate for a Regulatory Compliance Core Unit is in scope. Her grant is planned to evolve into incubating this core unit, alongside several other legal core units also entering the inaugural season of SES’s cohort incubator.  Meet Patrizia SES Legal introduced Patrizia on January 28th’s Weekly Status Update call. SES Legal previewed the plan to incubate critical legal infrastructure in a new cohort education model for the SES Incubator. Watch the recording here to meet Patrizia and learn about ways to support MakerDAO’s initiative of legal fortification at the DAO.
If I could post a gif here, it would be the “Boo this man! Booooooo!” gif

The call makes it sound like you are considering a general blacklist to make “terrorists” not able to access the core maker protocol, not retained only to off chain collateral. Maker should be researching ways to harden against such pressure rather than ways to assist in compliance. Regarding off chain collateral, is that not an agreement between an offchain legally recognized entity which represents Maker in the agreement and the off chain asset issuer?  Who is KYC performed on? Shouldn’t the issuer be KYCing the holders of their offchain asset and its onchain representation, with Maker only needing to verify they have a law abiding process in KYCing their own clients?
Great try to undermine what this entire space stands for, your proposal is exactly the reason it should all be decentralized, what makes you think that’s a good idea? Why don’t you open a bank?
Bruuuuuuuh the entire community has been anti-bank from the get—where have you been? Lost in translation—perhaps. Ain’t no banks here dude.
You can act like adding a KYC permission layer isn’t making it a bank, but it is
KYC/AML and DeFi should not appear together in the same sentence. It’s a real shame to even see such a proposal appear here. Thumbs down all the way.
Retro:  KYC/AML Compliance Research   No thanks, leave your KYC/AML Compliance Research at the door.

LefterisJP:  KYC/AML and DeFi should not appear together in the same sentence. It’s a real shame to even see such a proposal appear here.   I believe this is an unfair statement. The SES Core Unit team has been putting a lot of work with regards to monitoring the ever changing landscape of regulations and folks that don’t participate day in and day in this community will never care to notice. Its the equivalent of me telling you that the Hoopoe is the most popular bird in Greece. That don’t make no sense—I’m clueless to such subject. Βγάζει νόημα
Preferring to remain ignorant is always an irrational position. We will always choose the path that allows us to make informed decisions. This should be obvious.
I would argue you are now starting to get ignorant towards users and the space

Have you considered that this research can lead to more decentralization instead of less? Have you considered that, in fact, this has been the pattern all along that Maker has informed itself about legal risk and concluded that it needed to decentralize more? Have you considered that the pitchforks were out back then as well and that two years later everyone suddenly realized: oh yeah… they had been right all along. Because Maker is not naive like crypto twitter. It does its research, it stays away from ideological bias, and it makes informed decisions.
That’s interesting because i definitely see an ideological bias being applied here.

Informed should be led by a desire to harden against compliance and prevent regional obligations from being established. This, and the video call is framed more around falling in line with compliance and researching how best to accept the burden. Discussing blacklists, and “leaders in compliance” is framing out of line with the ethos of DAI imo. DAI should be aiming to be a leader in uncompliance. How a particular issuer deals with regulations is not our burden. Being aware of the resources needed to suitably issue an asset inline with regulations is something I could see being valuable research as this maintains offloading that responsibility to each asset issuer rather than leaving the burden on Maker. But this will be different in each region making it quite a hefty task. Imo better to support regional efforts to learn, integrate, and issue, than centralized that process as the dapps responsibility.

Most of the stuff that is mentioned as a topic for research in the proposal could indeed help get more informed and perhaps lead to even more decentralization in the future. What does not reconcile with this at least from the way I understand it is this:   The selection of AML tool(s) for MakerDAO with a demo conducted for the community to review.   I can’t see how selection/adoption of tools for AML in Maker’s products can foster decentralization.

The whole premise of the research is to look if and how KYC/AML aspects potentially relate to Maker. The tools are not going to be adopted outside of this context as part of the research. They are going to be looked into so we can understand what this all would mean in practice. I do agree this part shouldn’t go very far. For example we’re not going to invest time or money into integrating something if it’s ultimately not going to be used.

Thank you for this clarification Wouter.  The tools are not going to be adopted outside of this context as part of the research.  This is a key requirement imo and would love to see it just stay there, as a research project.

Screenshot from 2022-02-03 16-11-521147×636 215 KB  But it does seem there is intention to adopt and therefore integrate some of the compliance processes to be investigated here.  Screenshot from 2022-02-03 16-14-431259×693 240 KB  Seems we will evaluate and implement a technology provider which will address these regulatory challenges.  Screenshot from 2022-02-03 16-15-171313×526 195 KB  Where the next step in that implementation process is to evaluate and recommned tools which assist Maker in being compliant (note, not issuers, but Maker itself is set to make adjustments to fall into compliance) I’m having trouble squaring the slides with you saying none of this will be implemented on the Maker side.

I think the issue is that when reading “KYC/AML” people make assumptions about what the implementation looks like. For example, assume institutional users that need to identify their wallet or they can’t use the protocol. If the solution is: they have an identity NFT in their wallet so they can use Maker but it’s not required for other users… is that an issue? This is a hypothetical KYC solution that doesn’t enforce anything on anyone. As is always the case with research, let’s see what the outcome is, first. And let’s then make up our minds. Research assumes an open mind otherwise it’s quite pointless. And the last point I want to make: education goes in both directions. Compliance specialists may change their mind too. Learn more about DeFi, and maybe see new options.

edit cause summarized by i think your hypothetical is short on topical coverage. Overall, keep the compliance part out of maker implementation and I’m fine with knowing more about stuff. But I’d prefer if documentation and directional language reflected alignment with that. At present I don’t think it does. If that’s the plan, dope. Can easily reduce contention.

I’m shocked reading this …!!! Yes we need to collaborate etc etc but this is not something Maker DAO should do. The DAO should be constructed as nation state resistance as possible. I have been working for banks and other incombents institutions in the past. KYC/AML are all tools for oppersion and imo criminal scandals to spy and keep people poor and the incombents in power. I would like to propose to have all legal related work groups etc completely separately from the Maker DAO core groups. All funds and energy spend on this should be directly stopped and converted into a nation state recistance working group. If this does not happen and this proposal presses forward I will complely exit all my MKR and MKR positions and go work with a protocol that alliance more with the vision of what DeFi should be Decentralized!

I have worked on a solution to encrypt my data and then separate this data and only with criminal charges data could be unlocked … This is not a path to go true since they are not interested in this. This will fail if we go down this road!

amadeobrands:  I would like to propose to have all legal related work groups etc completely separately from the Maker DAO core groups. All funds and energy spend on this should be directly stopped and converted into a nation state recistance working group.   Let’s say this grant went instead to a nation state resistance working group. What would it be used for? Research? I would argue that KYC/AML and other regulations would inevitably be researched, whether to comply with them as little as possible or avoid them as much possible. This, I believe, is the purpose of the grant, and I wouldn’t say it goes against the DAO’s vision at all.

This whole proposal go’s against everything why I’m invested in MKR and use Maker DAO … I want to have parts of my financial life that is separated from the state… I’m not a criminal but just want to have a place to just do my finances without any government or corporations telling me what I can and can’t do. Maker DAO has started with pure intentions and as a big pushback against the out of control financial system. If we work with people like this we will get sucked into the current system and that means all will be lost. The legal working groups etc need to be completely seeprated. They can do research and give input but should be separated and have 0 power in protocol development… It is very important to seeprated all this legal and compliance stuff … If this will not happen tech will get super frustrated and things will not move forward.

Ideology meets the reality, I share the opinion that international regulation in the financial sector not only prevent criminal activities but also strongly against the idea of freedom, especially in autocratic states that get sensitive data presented on the platter to enforce political goals and strengthen their own power, oppress political opponents or shutting off their cash flows. It doesn’t even have to be autocratic states, if you have states or companies that are very centrally run, you only need a few corrupt people to abuse these sytsems. Even with all the KYC and AML, it seems that for one group all these rules do not apply. It is a high requirement to be allowed to work in this field at all. I don’t know how we will implement or enforce all these rules for individual wallets/vault users, however, I see a great opportunity with institutional wallets/users to enforce these rules. But concretely this will be shown with this work. I hope with the research maybe also all the prejudices will be cleared up. It must also be clearly said that MakerDao has the largest growth of enterprises and other protocols, so the recent development has also clearly been on the business side, it is relatively unattractive for individuals to use the protocol or manage a vault. Therefore, little to hardly any individuals are encouraged to deal with the protocol. Thats why the DAO moved more corporate friendly, it’s highly professional otherwise we wouldn’t have had the recent great developments. I would like to see more vaults or projects from individuals, maybe we will see a revival in the L2 if the protocol is implemented there, to attract them, so that these users can join the discussion, so there is no longer 100 % buissness oriented governance, but a mixed form.

Agreed  Let’s focus energy on development not this legal crap for the incombents. It is all fine if there are groups etc that want to impellent something with KYC stuff but they can do this as a completely seeprated entity. Maker DAO in it’s core needs to keep focusing on building and for example expanding to other L2’s like Arbitrum etc …
I have spent the past 5 years working on decentralized identity. I would like to offer my help to Patrizia.

amadeobrands:  I would like to propose to have all legal related work groups etc completely separately from the Maker DAO core groups. All funds and energy spend on this should be directly stopped and converted into a nation state recistance working group.   I sympathize with your concerns, I have a very similar vision when it comes to the protocol being neutral territory. However, when it comes to execution, it cannot work in the way you’re describing. “Maker DAO core groups” (Core Units) span everything from Protocol Engineering to finance to growth to people management to, yes, legal. Outsourcing our key challenges because we don’t like to deal with them is not smart. It merely relinquishes control over a key strategic area. I want to remind people of a post I made a while ago:    [Discussion] The DAO needs a serious discussion about legal structure   Agreed with @PaperImperium that we need to step up our legal strategy efforts. The discussion is obviously heating up in the US and I’m not going to speculate with hypotheses here, but, for me there is one important thing we should keep in mind when considering these matters: Any path that leads to legal AML/KYC requirements on the Dai token itself, should be a non-starter. The Dai token is of course fully permissionless and cannot be changed in its current form. But it’s not unthinkable that the wrong strategic choices on the legal front could lead to a future where the current ERC20 token, under legal pressure, is decoupled from the core protocol and a new, permissioned version is deployed. If that happens, we should just trigger emergency shutdown, call Dai a failed experiment and give up. Free and borderless transactions with Dai, accessible to the unbanked, high inflation economies, etc. is the core of our value proposition. Any taxation and even liability considerations should be secondary to that. In a world where CBDCs will be the official legal tender and every individual value transaction will be up for scrutiny by law enforcement, Dai has to be the free alternative or it should not exist. Because the digital age makes absolute surveillance an option, this will become an issue as important as free speech.   I still stand by every word of this. Yes, we need to double down on MakerDAO being the alternative to the CBDC surveillance scenario. Doing legal research into the challenges is not in contradiction to that; it is a critical element in ensuring that Maker will succeed in its ambition.     Tsokiskex:  I have spent the past 5 years working on decentralized identity. I would like to offer my help to Patrizia.   Now, this is the kind of reaction I’d like to see more of. We’ll be in touch to take you up on this offer.

wouter:  Doing legal research into the challenges is not in contradiction to that; it is a critical element in ensuring that Maker will succeed in its ambition.   This is the perspective I think is crucial here. SES could have done a better job sharing this intent in context of the research grant being presented/unveiled. To add to Wouter’s quote, here’s another direct quote taken from the presentation of the grant in question:  “Aiming to maintain the protocol permissionlessness and freely accessible DAI while mitigating or avoiding regulatory risk (sanctions)”  In my opinion research is needed to understand how to keep the core components away from regulatory influence/reach. Research is also needed to understand how Maker’s Real World Assets strategy can mitigate regulatory scrutiny. I’m aware the latter has been controversial, but I firmly believe it’s crucial for scaling this industry’s fruits and innovations beyond this cute little self-referential DeFi bubble we are all living in  cc @amadeobrands @banteg @LefterisJP
I, too, am interested in contributing to this research. Please reach out.
Simply if MakerDao will introduce a KYC system, community will fork it. There is no way for governments to stop crypto revolution. Every part is replaceable.

How about we read a little bit more and stop a little bit the FUD   twitter.com    MakerDAO Growth @MakerGrowth  Dai is stable, over-collateralized, decentralized, and immutable.   Dai can impact the real-world and we need to understand how it works.  Having enemies is a waste of time when we want to buidl the re-imagined currency for the world's wellness, the real-world's one. twitter.com/RuneKek/status…   Rune @RuneKek  Maker has always had a heavy focus on understanding the latest trends in regulation and  compliance so that we can deliver on the mission of creating DeFi that intersects with the real world while remaining decentralized and permissionless. https://t.co/fqhGTb3gGk    2:54 PM - 4 Feb 2022           5                2

If Maker steps into this direction it would make me heavily reconsider my investment. Any implementation of KYC/AML aimed at a private investor would damage Dai. If you think USDC Wrapper was bad publicity this will totally dismantle DAI reputation forever. I dont see any benefit to pursuing this. Are there institutions that came forward and would mint Dai if there was KYC/AML ?

There seems to be some misunderstandings around the scope of this research grant. Let me share some comments. First of all: The purpose of the research grant is NOT to implement KYC on DAI transactions or on any of the core features of the protocol (i.e. permissionless vaults / auction services / governance, etc.). Nothing in this research will be  an endorsement/plan of any kind to make KYC mandatory in Maker. As we have always said, DAI should always be  freely accessible and fungible and the features of the protocol must remain permissionless. However, there is a real regulatory and sanction risk that we can not ignore, and it can affect any one of us. We can not wait until the regulations are implemented at a national level and forces us into a reactive mode. The purpose of this grant is to investigate how the emerging international AML regulatory framework can impact Maker and how we could mitigate this risk. One of the risk mitigation strategies is to research technological solutions that are compatible with Maker’s values . They can include Decentralized Identity (DIDs), zero-knowledge-proofs, etc. compatible with a decentralized, permissionless, public protocol like MakerDAO. It is not only about regulatory risk mitigation. It is about turning risks into opportunities and competitive advantages. The main one is an unrestricted compromise to decentralization. Decentralization is our  main regulatory risk mitigation strategy. Entities like the FATF or SEC have explicitly recognized that projects with “sufficient decentralisation” can be excluded from regulatory scrutiny. Although we don’t always know what  exactly regulators understand under “sufficient decentralization” we do know that MakerDAO is extremely committed to decentralization, and therefore built a considerable competitive advantage, as well as regulatory resilience. But this is not enough. There are still centralization points to address, and each one of them is a regulatory access point. This important aspect will also be analyzed in the research grant. As always, we invite the community to give constructive feedback on how Maker should address legal and regulatory risks.

A wrapper on a vault that issues wrapped DAI would bypass the protections enshrined in MCD, and team seems shy to commit that’s off the table. This worries me. If we have compliant and non compliant vaults and can decommission vaults, such a path is a path to regulated DAI without changing the DAI code,  just adding wrappers. Will the team commit that producing a vault which generates wrapped DAI will never be produced by the Maker team? Will the team commit the compliance research is help institutions use Maker products but not impact Maker products. Because ya keep saying it wont impact them, but also keep saying we have a competitive advantage of being leader in compliance.

So slightly off-topic but you mentioned team a lot in your last post. There really isn’t a central Maker team in the same way there is for other DAO’s. Instead we have lots of teams called Core Units that do different things. SES (Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling) is focused on scaling up Maker and generally making DAI take over the world. Which is great and something we all want. GovAlpha (the team of which I’m a part) is focused on making governance as effective as possible and ensuring that proposals follow the governance processes as agreed by Governance and laid out in the MIPs. Any proposal that would impact the permissionless nature of Maker and/or DAI would require discussion and debate and would only be implemented if MKR Holders voted in favour (same as any other proposal.) tldr: The team can’t commit to anything, because there isn’t a central team. Individual Core Units will do their jobs  as laid out in their mandates. Any proposals they make are put to MKR Holders to decide. If you want to help ensure that no decisions are made that impact the permissionless nature of Maker and/or DAI, delegate your MKR to a Recognized Delegate, or otherwise engage with governance.

We have multiple members of core units in this forum who i would define as being employed by Maker who could make that commitment. I’ve seen multiple places on this topic where folks who work for core units of Maker have stated “the team is committed to never make a spell to force migrate vaults” I am only looking for the same level of commitment towards the above from folks who work for Core Units.

BlockEnthusiast:  We have multiple members of core units in this forum who i would define as being employed by Maker who could make that commitment.   So as an example, I could commit to leaving the DAO if MKR Holders approve a proposal which results in DAI becoming permissioned (to be clear, I’m not committing to that right now, I take my commitments seriously and would need to think more about it). But I will not commit to trying to prevent such a proposal from entering the governance process, because that’s directly contradictory to GovAlpha’s mandate. Other Core Units are in a position where their mandates don’t really have any relation to such a proposal, and wouldn’t be any position to do anything about it either way (other than commit to leaving if such a thing was approved.) The point is that if MKR Holders want something, there is ultimately nothing anyone in the Core Units can do to stop it in the long term. We can refuse or resign, but MKR Holders can find other employees that are willing to implement such proposals. So to reiterate, if you want to affect the direction which Maker takes, the best way to do that is to engage with governance either through delegation, or by continuing to engage in this forum.

So keep doing what I’m doing. Great! Lets try another framing then since we have to be very specific with language here. Many folks from Core Units have spoke on what they think this means. Many folks from Core Units have expectations about what the outcome of this all will be. Do any Core Units Folks currently hold expectations that the best route forward is to produce spells which create vaults which output wrapped DAI? We currently have This Proposal, and This Weekly Call. The weekly call covered how this Proposal fits into a broader picture which included compliance commitments. The discussion here seems to focus on, “this is just research it doesn’t mean anything” when the Weekly Call very clearly framed this as terminating on a commitment. We are partially here to  defining the mandate for a Regulatory Compliance Core Unit is in scope  I think that mandate should include that no compliance actions should be taken by Maker core infra which includes wrapping vaults to issue wrapped DAI. Does anyone here agree that should be part of the mandate?

I agree the preexisting assumptions of this grant (let’s navigate expected compliance obligations) are a bit worrisome. As a crypto-founder, bringing legal on board always led to unnecessarily conservative and heavily compliant recommendations that ultimately challenged the project. That’s not to say we were necessarily non-compliant otherwise, simply that the job of legal was to protect and the best way to do that was through clearly compliant recommendations which stifled development and scope. That said I don’t necessarily see it as unacceptable or disastrous to fund 3 months of exploratory work on these subjects. Simply that that needs to be put in a context of how to subvert rather than what sounds like happy submission. It would be much more expensive, of course, but I think anti-KYC/AML or pro-stablecoin/DAO lobbying would be a great use of funds if MakerDAO wanted to “prepare for the future”.

BlockEnthusiast:  I think that mandate should include that no compliance actions should be taken by Maker core infra which includes wrapping vaults to issue wrapped DAI. Does anyone here agree that should be part of the mandate?   This is the part that we’ll start a broader discussion about next week. We do need consensus in the community before we even start with the incubation program that would support this. SES suggests to have 3 incubation tracks, legal being one, and we have a list of core unit ideas that we’ll bring to the community before we move forward with it. There’s a lot of nuances and complications here, though. But again, we’ll get into that next week. For the sake of everyone’s weekend, I’ll ask for a bit more patience here. Assuming this core unit happens (not a given), assuming this particular condition makes sense, or otherwise a similar condition pending the research, I think that would make a lot of sense to put it in the mandate, yes. As for myself, I’ve quoted the post that pretty clearly outlines my commitment to a free and permissionless DAI, I believe.     uxt:  It would be much more expensive, of course, but I think anti-KYC/AML or pro-stablecoin/DAO lobbying would be a great use of funds if MakerDAO wanted to “prepare for the future”.   Also working on that.
Just gonna leave this here:  “a driving force towards autocracy is often preemptive compliance towards imagined expectations.”  Look forward to broader discussions next week

Too much controversy is being created about this, Maker can not remain inactive on this type of regulatory initiatives (unfortunately the essence of Defi is obviated). I agree that this should be addressed so that it does not affect in the long term.

This backlash could have been easily resolved if the grant was called something like “Limits of of decentralization in the face of regulatory realities” rather than “KYC/AML Compliance Research”. The first one implies they are researching way to strengthen decentralization efforts to avoid regulatory risks and the current name (and much of the grant wording) implies they are actively educating themselves on compliance in such as a way to attract regulators in the future. Think of the SEC in 2 years trying to bully and saying, “Look, MakerDAO even paid for compliance research so they knew what was coming and should be held accountable for not doing more.” This grant feels like it will backfire tremendously, not entirely because of the content of the grant itself, but the implications with the wording and goals of the research which can easily be misconstrued by regulators in the future (as well as others).

The fact is regulatory change is coming to Defi, like it or not. The community has an opportunity to protect decentralization and censorship resistance in light of any proposed changes. It seems the grant provides the research to do exactly that.

I think that in light of the controversy around this initiative a discussion about the community’s values around decentralization and permissionlessness becomes important. This is logically separate from the research grant but it would be very clarifying. Personally I think that a) permissionless DAI use is a core part of Maker. Weakening that in any way breaks not only the project’s core values but also its long-term prospects. Note that there exist faster cheaper centralized entities with different stabilisation mechanisms that offer usd stable tokens. b) permissionless DAI creation (with nontrivial DCs, on major assets) is also a core part of Maker. No matter what gets built around it, losing this is a bit like losing permissionless DAI. You end up with the worst of the centralized and decentralized worlds. Both operationally and in terms of what you represent. c) permissioned vaults for specific borrowers (for instance all of RWA) is totally OK.

Compliance and user privacy are not necessarily against each other. You just need to find the right tools — such as DID and zero-knowledge proof — then you can get the best part from both worlds. zCloak Network has been working on such a solution for more than a year. We’d happy to assist Patrizia to investigate the KYC/AML research for MakerDAO. You can check out our site: https://zcloak.network, and DM me anytime.

zCloak:  zCloak Network has been working on such a solution for more than a year. We’d happy to assist Patrizia to investigate the KYC/AML research for MakerDAO. You can check out our site: https://zcloak.network , and DM me anytime.   Thank you.     zCloak:  Compliance and user privacy are not necessarily against each other. You just need to find the right tools — such as DID and zero-knowledge proof — then you can get the best part from both worlds.   The thing is of course that privacy is not the same as openness and permissionlessness, and they should definitely not be confused. If I’m a protester in Belarus and I try to use DAI, it’s good that the system won’t try to identify me, but it can still exclude me altogether, if I don’t have the right access pass that shows I’m government-approved. I am not a lawyer, but I would assume that any legal defense for permissionless usage has to come from the angle of the rights of individuals, constitutional rights, or human rights. Basically any section of the law that fundamentally curtails government power. Which is why, in countries that call themselves democratic, there is an argument to be made. Privacy is part of that same space and very important too, but it is not synonymous. This is why I have a hard time seeing how privacy solutions can fundamentally fix the issue. The solution has to come from immutability (no one can revoke access) or decentralization (control is so diversified that it’s unfeasible any government can successfully manipulate it), hardened as much as possible with legal protection. For this legal protection we need research, because ultimately MakerDAO involves people. (Rights of corporations as opposed to individuals is a very different matter, which relates to institutional vaults and RWAs.)

I covered this project for my community lately since I have always been interested in this project. That is no more. And what a shame, there was potential for something here. Time and time we have seen what happens when DeFi projects succumb to the pressure of the traditional system and especially the nemesis of crypto that is FATF. I told them to stay away and so we will. Good luck to MakerDao, you have turned your back against decentralisation - one can only imagine the consequences that will come of this.

wouter:  I am not a lawyer, but I would assume that any legal defense for permissionless usage has to come from the angle of the rights of individuals, constitutional rights, or human rights. Basically any section of the law that fundamentally curtails government power. Which is why, in countries that call themselves democratic, there is an argument to be made. Privacy is part of that same space and very important too, but it is not synonymous. This is why I have a hard time seeing how privacy solutions can fundamentally fix the issue. The solution has to come from immutability (no one can revoke access) or decentralization (control is so diversified that it’s unfeasible any government can successfully manipulate it), hardened as much as possible with legal protection. For this legal protection we need research, because ultimately MakerDAO involves people. (Rights of corporations as opposed to individuals is a very different matter, which relates to institutional vaults and RWAs.)   We understand what you said. Permissionlessness is definitely a virtue of crypto and we value that. However, we are not living in a bubble. There are governments, courts and armies around us, in the real life. We are somehow afraid that, without doing what we are doing right now, we won’t get permissionless blockchain. Instead, we will get permissioned blockchain with no user privacy—the end of crypto basically. So you see we are trying to explore a middle ground here, because landing in the middle ground is still better than landing at “their side”. We hope this makes sense to you.

It’d be great to integrate with Signata:   sata.technology    Signata | Decentralized Identity and the Future of Finance Decentralized Identity and the Future of Finance.      They let users connect their public key with a KYC-provider, all in one ecosystem. In this way, the user doesn’t have to KYC at every platform that will implement this, but can just use his KYC’ed address.

From the Whitepaper: “[Signata’s platform] will allow for service providers to authenticate users, collect payments, and provide access control to systems without knowing any identifiable information about the user - unless they want to collect that information themselves and the user consents to the collection of the information.” I think something like this could be very useful - either a SATA token for every user or Maker’s own version.

I have so many thoughts on this proposal and the community’s reaction to the propsal. At the broadest level, the visceral reaction we witnessed at just the mention of looking into the implications of compliance and how it could be implemented seems to reflect a misunderstanding of how truly decentralized protocols work. The situation brings the Uniswap delisting controversy to mind for a similiar reason. First, the front end most people are familiar with is run by the Oasis team, which is independent of MakerDAO (as far as I’m aware). Other independent front ends are also popular, such as DefiSaver. Each of those could choose to implement or not implement compliance checks on their own. Second, even if MakerDAO were to somehow force these front ends to implement KYC and AML checks, new ones would spring up and the contracts can also be used on a command line level by anyone. Third, no one has suggested DAI would be subject to compliance checks. From what I can tell, this was primarily designed as a scoping exercise to determine what the risks are, what the benefits are, and how could any compliance be implemented at the edges of the system to enable easier integration with RWA and large financial or enterprise institutions. For example, could a core unit create a specific front end and platform where only KYC/AMLed persons interact with each other? Could certain entities be setup outside the DAO to facilitate interactions with the smart contract system while enabling counterparties to use that entity as a compliance check? There is a real value in seeing where bridges can be built to traditional finance, and those bridges don’t necessarily require abandoning the principles that so many people came in here to defend. I wish that we had the trust of the community to explore that opportunity without fear of being cancelled.

I was one of the first to test your protocol, I took risks, but I believed that I was doing something big for humanity.  And now you are destroying your reputation with this proposal, nullifying our efforts to implement your protocol.  With such offers, there is no more room for your project.  It’s horrible

I imagine that the push towards this study was partially a consequence of the recent push toward growth in RWA as collateral.  The fact is that transactions for RWA have to be done under the auspices of central authorities that can in a moment’s notice change or break contractual agreements.  If MKR were to expand exposure in these areas, it does seem prudent to explore the risks involved.  Though some here have advocated sectioning off RWA as it’s own area for compliance, a growing portfolio of RWA could be an attack vector for authorities to target in order to coerce changes in other areas of the protocol.  What would be the impact of collateral seizures, fines to partners, legal action against core contributors?  What level of noncompliance might lead to such actions and in what locales?  If possible, how could loss from such actions be mitigated or prevented?  What levels of compliance cede too much power to authorities and undermine the MKR community?  When is it the right time to address or attempt to influence rapidly changing regulations?  What would be the costs?  Those are a few questions off the top of my head that I have.  I’m sure there is many more I haven’t thought of.  As Maker has chosen to grow in the direction of bridging virtual and real world assets, answering these questions is going to matter more and more.  The alternative is to stay completely in the virtual world.

Traster_Tray:  Though some here have advocated sectioning off RWA as it’s own area for compliance, a growing portfolio of RWA could be an attack vector for authorities to target in order to coerce changes in other areas of the protocol.   Thank you for your comments. Excellent questions for us all to engage with and answer thoroughly and thoughtfully. My Poll vote in favor of this Declaration of Intent was an unfortunate result of user error MIP13c3-SP12: Declaration of Intent - Invest in short-term bonds. I’ll go into more detail on why I intended to vote NO in my March month-end Delegate Platform summary post. But let me mention here that in addition to disfavoring US Federal Reserve counterparty risk generally, I have a visceral objection to taking our beautiful permissionless assets off-chain and parking them in the very assets everyone should be getting out of. @Herbalremidy also raised the point recently that directly holding US Treasuries through regulated TradFi institutions could be viewed as compromising strong arguments we now have in our favor that distinguish MakerDAO from market participants within reach of current KYC/AML regulations.

Thank you @wouter always good quality conversations here. However, I do not agree. From personal experiences, it is not good to mix too much legal with tech. Best to then maybe do this via a different DAO structure etc with a completely separate and transparent budget and let the community decide? If we go down the route Maker DAO is now taking I think the work DAO is at that stage just a hype word. Would love to see Maker DAO just as a core stable protocol and not a political multi DAO workgroup forest. Overall I am a big supporter and user and hope to see more cool products soon.
